guiding_thinkers: Karl Marx, Friedrich Engels, Antonio Gramsci, Rosa Luxemburg
description: Analyzes society through class struggle, material conditions, and the contradictions of capitalism

assumptions: Material conditions of production determine social consciousness
History progresses through class struggle and modes of production
Social being determines consciousness, not vice versa
Capitalism contains internal contradictions leading to its transformation
Human essence is realized through social labor and production
Ideas and culture reflect and legitimize material class relations
core_tensions: Forces vs Relations of Production - technological capacity versus social organization
Use Value vs Exchange Value - concrete utility versus abstract market value
Labor vs Capital - those who produce versus those who own
Base vs Superstructure - economic foundation versus ideological forms
scope_conditions: Applies to societies with developed division of labor and private property
Cannot explain pre-class societies or post-class communist society fully
Requires material production as basis of social life

primary_entities: Classes - groups defined by relationship to means of production
Mode of Production - unity of forces and relations defining an epoch
Commodity - product with both use and exchange value for market
Labor Power - human capacity to work, sold as commodity
Capital - self-expanding value through exploitation of labor
relations: Exploitation - extraction of surplus value from labor
Class antagonism - structural opposition of class interests
levels_of_analysis: Economic base - forces and relations of production
Political superstructure - state, law, and institutions

change_mechanisms: Contradiction-driven crisis - internal contradictions generate systemic crises
Class struggle - conflict between classes drives historical change
Mode of production transformation - productive forces outgrow relations
temporal_patterns: Historical materialism - modes of production succeed through revolution
Crisis cycles - periodic crises of overproduction and profitability
Tendential laws - long-term trends like falling rate of profit
transformation_processes: Revolution - fundamental restructuring of class relations
Proletarianization - expansion of wage labor relations
Primitive accumulation - violent separation from means of production

key_concepts: Surplus value - value created by workers beyond their wages
Alienation - separation from product, process, species-being, and others
False consciousness - ideology that misrepresents real conditions
Commodity fetishism - social relations appear as relations between things
Primitive accumulation - violent separation from means of production
Reserve army of labor - unemployed maintaining wage pressure
analytical_methods: Dialectical materialism - analyzing contradictions in material conditions
Historical materialism - tracing modes of production through history
Class analysis - identifying class positions and interests
Critique of political economy - revealing capitalism's inner workings
ideal_state: From each according to ability, to each according to need
Free association of producers controlling their labor
End of prehistory, beginning of human history

trait_definitions.trait_description: Method of analysis through contradictions and their resolution
Grounding analysis in material conditions and production
Critique of existing social relations and ideology

critique_patterns.fix: Specify class position of {actors} and interests in {process}

critique_patterns.diagnostic: Ideas or consciousness as prime mover
Change through will alone without material conditions
critique_patterns.fix: Revolution requires both objective conditions and subjective organization

historical_context: Emerged in 19th century industrial capitalism, evolved through 20th century revolutionary movements
